Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Story:
I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It’s important for the family.” My heart thudded. I knew what it meant—standing before everyone, reciting the prayers, guiding the rituals just as my grandmother had. It was an honor, but also a heavy responsibility. I could almost hear my father’s voice: “Tradition keeps us together.” I wanted to make them proud, to show I valued our roots.

But then my work phone buzzed. The homeowner’s voice was urgent: “The deck is unsafe. My kids can’t play outside until it’s fixed. Can you come today?” As a carpenter, I knew the risks of leaving a damaged deck unattended. My clients trusted me to keep their homes safe, and I prided myself on never letting them down.

I felt pulled in two directions—my family counting on me to uphold our traditions, and my client relying on me to restore their home. The weight of both expectations pressed on my chest, and I wondered how I could possibly choose between them.
